head.title: Installing on RPM-based Linux (CentOS, Fedora, OpenSuse, RedHat)

doc:subsection.name: install-rpm
doc:subsection.doc:heading: Install the Server

dd.p: The RabbitMQ server is included in Fedora, so for Fedora and RHEL users we recommend to install the rabbitmq-server package via the distribution's package manager.

Alternatively, install rabbitmq-server-&version-server;-noarch.rpm (which you can download from the download page). We recommend using your distribution's packaged version of Erlang to run the server. See the server download page for more information.

doc:subsection.p: We strongly recommend using a packaged version of Erlang to run the server. This is part of Fedora, and in EPEL for RHEL. To enable EPEL on your Red Hat machine, see the EPEL FAQ. Then just yum install erlang.

Note to users of RHEL 5 and derived distributions (e.g. CentOS 5): Due to the EPEL package update policy, EPEL 5 contains Erlang version R12B-5, which is relatively old. rabbitmq-server supports R12B-5, but performance may be lower than for more recent Erlang versions, and certain non-core features are not supported (SSL support, HTTP-based plugins). Therefore, we recommend that you install the most recent stable version of Erlang. The easiest way to do this is to use a package repository provided for this purpose by the owner of the EPEL Erlang package. Enable it by invoking (as root):
and then install or update erlang with yum install erlang.

dd.p: The server should start using defaults. You can customise the RabbitMQ environment. Also see how to configure components.

The server is not started as a daemon by default when the RabbitMQ server package is installed. To start the daemon by default when the system boots, as an administrator run chkconfig rabbitmq-server on.
As an administrator, start and stop the server as usual using /sbin/service rabbitmq-server stop/start/etc.

Note: The server is set up to run as system user rabbitmq. If you change the location of the Mnesia database or the logs, you must ensure the files are owned by this user (and also update the environment variables).

dl.dd: See the Generic Unix or Linux section for info on rabbitmqctl commands and logging.
